Speaker: revised
Dialogue: September 23, 1991

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: Your Majesty would wish to know the true facts concerning the island of Hispanola, our first settlement in the New World, and the activities there of your servant, Christopher Columbus, Admiral of the Ocean Sea, Governor of that Island.  You will remember with what hopes and promises he beguiled us -- the truth is that he now presides over a state of chaos, degradation and madness beyond imagining.

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: From the beginning, Columbus proved himself incapable of managing the affairs of the island.  He appointed his brothers to important positions, at once injuring the pride and dignity of the nobles who had gone with him.  He promised to build a city, the City of Isabel, named after Your Majesty.  What he actually built was nothing but a collection of huts, and that in the wrong place, for all of it was easily swept away by rain and mud. Is that not so, Brother Buyl?

Speaker: brother buyl
Dialogue: Yes, Your Honor.

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: He promised gold.  Not finding the easy quantities he promised, Columbus commanded each Indian to pay an annual tribute.  Most being unable to, they were barbarously punished, against the express wish of Your Christian Majesties...

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: Since provocation and injustice never ceases, many of the Indians have fled to the forests, or have begun to slay the Christians.

Speaker: isabel
Dialogue: Could it be so?

Speaker: brother buyl
Dialogue: Yes, Your Majesty.

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: But there is worse.  From the beginning, he forced the nobles to undergo physical labor, treating them equally with the Indians, all of them reduced to slavery.  When the nobleman Adrian de Moxica protested against such treatment...  Is that not true also, Brother Buyl?

Speaker: brother buyl
Dialogue: Yes, Your Honor.  It is all true. All of it.  I saw it with my own eyes.

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: He has lost control.  His great arrogance has led him into depravity.  He encourages our soldiers to marry the native women. He promised a paradise, but he has made a hell full of all its horrors.

Speaker: isabel
Dialogue: Is that the man I knew, Treasurer Sanchez?

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: Yes, Your Majesty.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Fernando!

Speaker: fernando
Dialogue: Diego!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Diego!  Aren't you going to kiss your brother?

Speaker: marchena
Dialogue: Diego, take Fernando to the dining hall.  He must be hungry.

Speaker: diego
Dialogue: Yes, Father.

Speaker: marchena
Dialogue: Diego is a bright boy -- a pleasure to teach -- but so serious... Brothers should be raised together, Colon.  Even brothers from different mothers...

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Father, I am doing what I think is the best for him.  And he has the teacher I would have chosen for myself.

Speaker: marchena
Dialogue: Just be careful you don't lose him.

Speaker: marchena
Dialogue: I have something for you.

Speaker: marchena
Dialogue: You will be heard at the University of Salamanca...

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: God... That's in a week!

Speaker: marchena
Dialogue: That's what it says.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: How did you manage it?

Speaker: marchena
Dialogue: With some difficulty.  I had to promise them you were not a total fool.

Speaker: marchena
Dialogue: Why do you wish to sail west?

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: To open a new route to Asia.  At the moment there are only two ways of reaching it...

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: By sea, sailing around the African Continent -- the journey takes a year...

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Or by land...

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: By sailing West across the Ocean Sea.

Speaker: marchena
Dialogue: How can you be so certain?  The Ocean is said to be infinite.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Ignorance!  I believe the Indies are no more than 750 leagues west of the Canary Islands.

Speaker: marchena
Dialogue: How can you be so certain?

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: The calculations of Toscanelli Marin de Tyr, Esdras...

Speaker: marchena
Dialogue: Esdras is a Jew.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: So was Christ!

Speaker: marchena
Dialogue: Two minutes... and already you're a dead man.  Don't let passion overwhelm you, Colon.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: I'll try to remember that, Marchena...

Speaker: marchena
Dialogue: Father Marchena!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Passion is something one cannot control!

Speaker: marchena
Dialogue: You get so carried away when you are being contradicted!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: I've been contradicted all my life... Eternity!

Speaker: marchena
Dialogue: Only God knows the meaning of such words, my son.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Diego.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Would you like to come and stay with us?

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: I'll do whatever makes you happy.

Speaker: diego
Dialogue: I am happy, Father.

Speaker: fernando
Dialogue: Look, Father!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Fernando!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Fernando!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Executions.  In the square.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: They've agreed to see me in a week.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: I could be gone for years.

Speaker: beatrix
Dialogue: I know.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: I haven't given you much of a life.

Speaker: beatrix
Dialogue: Well... that's true.  I have a child by a man who won't marry me!  Who's always leaving...

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Are we going to argue?

Speaker: beatrix
Dialogue: I'd love to argue with you sometimes.  But you're never here!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Perhaps I was never meant to live with a woman...

Speaker: beatrix
Dialogue: I find that hard to believe.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Fernando, don't you think we are lucky to live with such a beautiful woman?

Speaker: monk
Dialogue: Christopher Columbus?

Speaker: arojaz
Dialogue: You say Asia can be found by sailing west?

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Yes, your Eminence.  The voyage should not take more than six or seven weeks.

Speaker: arojaz
Dialogue: Unfortunately, Don Colon, that is precisely where our opinions differ...  Are you familiar with the work of Aristotle?  Erathostene?  Ptolemeus?

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: I am, Your Eminence

Speaker: arojaz
Dialogue: Then you cannot ignore that according to their calculations, the circumference of the Earth is approximately...  22,000 leagues or more.  Which makes the ocean... uncrossable.

Speaker: arojaz
Dialogue: But you may have found new evidence proving that these men of knowledge are totally mistaken!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Your Excellencies are aware of the statements of Marin de Tyr?

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Then you are also aware that his theories contradict Ptolemeus... De Tyr believes the Ocean to be only 750 leagues...

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: The Florentine Toscanelli and the French Cardinal Pierre d'Ailly both think that Marin de Tyr is accurate in his calculations.  And therefore, that the ocean can be crossed.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Seven weeks.  Six, during the summer months.

Speaker: arojaz
Dialogue: Marin de Tyr is wrong -- and has been corrected many times over the centuries by the finest geographers. Your voyage, Don Colon, would take a year!

Speaker: vicuna
Dialogue: How would the crew survive without being able to land for fresh water? Water is undrinkable after six weeks!  You'd never be able to turn back!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: We wouldn't have to turn back!  We would find land at this point!

Speaker: arojaz
Dialogue: Senor Colon, an experienced captain such as yourself will understand our concern with the crew.  I am not willing to have on my conscience the loss of men who would have relied upon our judgment.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Excellency, you are right.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: I am a seaman, not a scholar... But as a simple man craving for knowledge, I have read all the work of these renowned geographers and discovered that none of them could agree on the exact width of this ocean...

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Therefore, as a modest man, I wonder:  who is right?

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Who is right?  This question remains unanswered.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Your Eminence, there is only one way to settle the matter.  And that is to make the journey.  I am ready to risk my life to prove it possible.

Speaker: arojaz
Dialogue: Your life, and that of others!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: If they agree to follow me, yes.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Trade, Your Excellency.  According to Marco Polo, the Kingdom of China is one of the richest of the world. Even the meanest buildings are roofed with gold.

Speaker: arojaz
Dialogue: Is that all that interests you? Gold?

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: No.  The Portuguese have already discovered black-skinned people.  I, too, will find other populations -- and bring them to the word of God.

Speaker: arojaz
Dialogue: Christopher -- Christo Ferens -- the Bearer of the Cross!

Speaker: monk
Dialogue: And Colon -- the one who populates!

Speaker: arojaz
Dialogue: If God intended our proximity to Asia, do you believe he would have waited for you to show it to the world?

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Did He not choose a carpenter's son to reveal Himself to the world?

Speaker: arojaz
Dialogue: So you consider yourself the chosen one?

Speaker: arojaz
Dialogue: Don't you realize your words could be considered heretical?

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Blind faith is what I consider heresy!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Asia can be found to the west -- and I will prove it.

Speaker: arojaz
Dialogue: IF-GOD-WILLS-IT!

Speaker: arojaz
Dialogue: The Treasurer of Spain honors us with his presence.

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: The State has some reason to be interested in this man's proposition, Your Eminence...

Speaker: arojaz
Dialogue: The Judgment is ours!

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: Naturally.  But I would really deplore the loss of such a potential opportunity for Spain for a... dispute over a point of geography.

Speaker: arojaz
Dialogue: He is a mercenary!  Did he not already try to convince the King of Portugal of his absurd notions?

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: Indeed.  The world is full of mercenaries -- and states often make use of them, when it benefits them.  My only concern is the welfare and prosperity of Spain.

Speaker: arojaz
Dialogue: You would use your influence to assist this... intriguer?

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: You know, Your Eminence, the fascinating thing about power, is that what can be given so effortlessly...

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: ... can so easily be taken away.

Speaker: marchena
Dialogue: ... and therefore nothing could justify the participation of Your Highnesses in the venture that relies upon such feeble assumptions, and which any man of knowledge would take to be impractical... if not impossible.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: They didn't listen.  They didn't want to listen!

Speaker: marchena
Dialogue: You mustn't give way to despair. You must wait.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Wait!  I've waited seven years already!  How much longer do you want me to wait?

Speaker: marchena
Dialogue: If God intends you to go, then you will go.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Damn God!

Speaker: marchena
Dialogue: Colon!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Damn all of you!  You all set up theories based on what?  You never leave the safety of your studies! Go out!  Find out what the world is about and then tell me something I can listen to!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: These don't mean anything!  They're full of assumptions!  Out of the heads of old men who've never been past the end of their gardens!

Speaker: marchena
Dialogue: No...!  My books...!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: All of them!  Just lies!

Speaker: marchena
Dialogue: Colon!  Don't!

Speaker: fernando
Dialogue: Father?

Speaker: diego
Dialogue: Sssshhhh...!  One can't speak to a man doing penance.

Speaker: fernando
Dialogue: What can you do?

Speaker: diego
Dialogue: Nothing.  That's the point, Fernando.

Speaker: pinzon
Dialogue: Ah, thank God!  I've been looking all over Seville for you!  Never expected to find a sailor in a monastery, eh?

Speaker: pinzon
Dialogue: Name's Pinzon, by the way.  Martin Alonzo Pinzon.  I'm a ship owner from Palos...

Speaker: pinzon
Dialogue: Is he a spy?

Speaker: pinzon
Dialogue: What is it?  Are you a Trappist?

Speaker: pinzon
Dialogue: Vow of silence...?  Penance?

Speaker: pinzon
Dialogue: Jesus!  Just my luck!

Speaker: pinzon
Dialogue: Listen.  I'll do the talking for both of us.  You just nod.  Agreed? Just as I do with the wife.

Speaker: pinzon
Dialogue: I know that the Commission turned you down, right?  What do you expect?  You're a foreigner... But I want to help you.

Speaker: pinzon
Dialogue: You wonder why I believe in you? Hey, I am a seaman.  And we don't like to be told where to go, and where not to go.

Speaker: pinzon
Dialogue: I don't look like it, but I have friends at the Court.  The Treasurer of Aragon, for example.  He finances me.  His name's Santangel.  Ever heard of him?

Speaker: pinzon
Dialogue: He can get you an audience with the Queen!  You know why...?  She owes him money.  That's how it is.  You -- me -- the Queen -- the world and his mistress -- agreed?

Speaker: pinzon
Dialogue: So.  What do you say?

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Where can I meet this man?

Speaker: pinzon
Dialogue: Immediately.

Speaker: santangel
Dialogue: These people built Granada... Centuries ago!  It is a great victory over the Moors, Don Colon -- and yet what a tragedy it is!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Is this a good time to meet her?

Speaker: santangel
Dialogue: It couldn't be better.  Victors can't say no.

Speaker: santangel
Dialogue: Your Excellency... truly grateful... your help... as ever...

Speaker: isabel
Dialogue: Rise...!  Come forward!

Speaker: isabel
Dialogue: I should not even be listening to you, since my council said no.  But Santangel tells me you are a man of honor and sincerity... And Sanchez, that you are not a fool.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: No more than the woman who said she would take Granada from the Moors.

Speaker: isabel
Dialogue: The ocean is uncrossable?

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: What did they say about Granada before today?

Speaker: isabel
Dialogue: That she was impregnable.

Speaker: isabel
Dialogue: I cannot ignore the verdict of my council.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Surely you can do anything you want.

Speaker: isabel
Dialogue: How little you know.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: May I speak freely?

Speaker: isabel
Dialogue: You show no inclination to speak otherwise!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: I know what I see.  I see someone who doesn't accept the world as it is.  Who's not afraid.  I see a women who thinks... "What if?"...

Speaker: isabel
Dialogue: A woman?

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Forgive me... but you're the only Queen I know.

Speaker: isabel
Dialogue: Then we are equal... since you are the only sailor I know!

Speaker: isabel
Dialogue: How old are you, Senor Colon?

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Thirty seven, Your Majesty... And you?

Speaker: isabel
Dialogue: Thirty eight...

Speaker: isabel
Dialogue: You will be informed of our decision.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Actually, I thought you were younger than me!

Speaker: administrator
Dialogue: ... and he demands... he DEMANDS to be made a Knight, with the right to bear the Golden Spurs!  He will receive the title of Don Cristobal Colon -- which will be extended to his descendants for ever more...

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: Go on!

Speaker: administrator
Dialogue: He will be named Great Admiral of the Ocean Sea.  Viceroy of the West Indies... Governor of all islands or lands discovered or as will be discovered with his help...

Speaker: administrator
Dialogue: The highest titles of nobility, Your Excellency!  To an immigrant sheltered by monks!

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: Furthermore he will receive one eight of all wealth or monies, precious gems, pearls, metals, spices and other lucrative sources conquered within the boundaries of his admiralty...

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: It's very underdone.

Speaker: administrator
Dialogue: Underdone!  It's monstrous, Excellency!

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: No, the pheasant.  It's almost raw.

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: You worry too much, Carvajal... The man will have to lower his demands. Believe me, he WILL!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: I WON'T!

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: We have considered your -- demands very carefully, Senor Colon... Your expectations are... excessive, in every way.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: If I am right, my requests are fair!

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: We have prepared our own contract...

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: No...

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: No?

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: NO...!  I have waited too long, fought too hard.  Now you expect me to take all the risks while you take the profit!  No... I will not be your servant!

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: I remind you, Senor Colon, that you are in no position to bargain with me.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: I'm not bargaining!

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: Then you are too ambitious.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: And were you never ambitious, Excellency?  Or is ambition only a virtue among the nobles, a fault for the rest of us?

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: If you won't accept our proposal, we'll simply find someone who will.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: If you can do that, Excellency -- I'll become a monk!

Speaker: isabel
Dialogue: You were right, Don Sanchez... His demands could never be granted.

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: Never, Your Majesty.  Although...

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: ... Although one may always renegotiate a contract.  Especially signed by Royal Hands.

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: ... Into a monk...

Speaker: isabel
Dialogue: Call him back!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: YEEEEEEES!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: She said yes.

Speaker: beatrix
Dialogue: Thank God...

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: If I ever come back, I swear I will...

Speaker: beatrix
Dialogue: I'm not asking you to swear to anything.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: I don't want you to wait for me.

Speaker: beatrix
Dialogue: That's something you can't decide.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: There aren't any monsters, Fernando. The only monsters are in here...  Watch!

Speaker: fernando
Dialogue: I want to go with you!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: There'll be a time.

Speaker: fernando
Dialogue: You promise?  Do you swear on St. Christopher...?

Speaker: fernando
Dialogue: Do you swear on all the Holy Saints in heaven?

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Yes... Yes, I do... On all of them!

Speaker: marchena
Dialogue: In Nomine Patris et Filius, et Spiritus Sancti.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Forgive me, Father.  For I have sinned.

Speaker: marchena
Dialogue: I am listening, my son.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Father, I have betrayed my family. I betrayed my men.  And I betrayed you.

Speaker: marchena
Dialogue: What are you saying?

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: I lied.  The journey will be longer than I said.

Speaker: marchena
Dialogue: How long?

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: I am not sure... It could be twice the distance.

Speaker: marchena
Dialogue: May God forgive you...!  You must tell them!  You must tell your men!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: If I tell them, they won't follow me.  You know that I am right, Father.  You trust me...

Speaker: marchena
Dialogue: My son, my son...  Christopher, you must speak to them. And if you don't I will.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: You are bound by an oath, Father.

Speaker: marchena
Dialogue: I believed in you...

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Give me absolution.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Give me absolution, Father!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Be good to your mother, Fernando. Do you promise?

Speaker: beatrix
Dialogue: Speak to Diego.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Diego!  Here!

Speaker: santangel
Dialogue: Take care of my investment, wherever you're going!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: I have to tell you Santangel.  I don't know where on earth I am going!

Speaker: sailor
Dialogue: Vaya con Dios!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Due west, Captain Mendez.  And may God be with us...

Speaker: mendez
Dialogue: God be with us admiral.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: What is it Mendez?  Speak!

Speaker: mendez
Dialogue: Well... It's the men, Sir.  They wonder how you know our position. We've lost sight from land days ago...

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: And what do you think Mendez?

Speaker: mendez
Dialogue: Well, I surely know what a quadrant is!  But I've never seen it used at night before.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Come over here.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Now, find the North Star.  Do you have it?

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Don't move!  A mistake of one degree and we'll be off 6,000 leagues!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: What do you read?

Speaker: mendez
Dialogue: Twenty eight.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: That's it.  The twenty eighth parallel.  And we'll follow it until we reach land.

Speaker: alonso
Dialogue: How do you know land is on the twenty eighth parallel?

Speaker: alonso
Dialogue: Chicken-ass face!

Speaker: alonso
Dialogue: Shit!

Speaker: alonso
Dialogue: I never seen heat like this!  Not even in Las Minas!

Speaker: sailor
Dialogue: The water's going putrid in the barrels.

Speaker: alonso
Dialogue: You'll be drinking your own piss... For the glory of Spain... and Admiral Colon...!  Bastard!

Speaker: alonso
Dialogue: What are you listening to, chicken ass?

Speaker: sailor
Dialogue: Ah, leave him alone.  He's doing no harm.

Speaker: alonso
Dialogue: With a face like that?  I don't want you looking at me.  You hear?

Speaker: alonso
Dialogue: He's the devil's child...

Speaker: sailor
Dialogue: We'll all go crazy...

Speaker: sailor
Dialogue: Culo de galina es el hijo del demonio...

Speaker: alonso
Dialogue: We should have seen land.

Speaker: sailor
Dialogue: We left three weeks ago, Alonso. Can't be that near.

Speaker: alonso
Dialogue: Can't be that far, I say.  Also, I don't like the smell of the sea around here.  Smells like a cunt. Bad sign...

Speaker: cook
Dialogue: Of course it smells like it!  That's why sailors take to the sea!

Speaker: alonso
Dialogue: And why does this one take to the sea?  Nobody knows.  Never says a word...

Speaker: mendez
Dialogue: To your post!  At once!

Speaker: ship's boy
Dialogue: Mark.  Twenty nine, Sir!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Six hundred and twenty nine.

Speaker: ship's boy
Dialogue: Six hundred and twenty nine!

Speaker: officer
Dialogue: Six hundred and twenty nine, Sir!

Speaker: pinzon
Dialogue: I heard.

Speaker: officer
Dialogue: Captain, I don't understand.

Speaker: pinzon
Dialogue: I think I do.

Speaker: mendez
Dialogue: Continue rowing!

Speaker: alonso
Dialogue: To where?

Speaker: officer
Dialogue: Captain Pinzon requests permission to board.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Granted.

Speaker: pinzon
Dialogue: You lied!  You cheated!  We're way past 750 leagues!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Six days ago, yes.

Speaker: pinzon
Dialogue: You must be mad...!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: We have to keep the hopes of these men alive!

Speaker: pinzon
Dialogue: We're on the verge of a mutiny, Colon!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: You think I don't know that?

Speaker: pinzon
Dialogue: We're lost!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: The land is there.  I know it!

Speaker: pinzon
Dialogue: You don't know anything!  Listen Colon, these are my ships, right? So I'm telling you we're turning back!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: And then what?  Half of the water has gone, the rest is nearly putrid! You know that!

Speaker: pinzon
Dialogue: Jesus Maria!  I should have never listened to you!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: You never did.  You did all the talking for both of us, remember?

Speaker: pinzon
Dialogue: You bloody...

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Pinzon, Pinzon... All we can do now is go forward!  Think about that!

Speaker: pinzon
Dialogue: You tell that to them!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: You're right.  Let the men decide.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Who gave you the order to come on board?

Speaker: alonso
Dialogue: God doesn't want us to cross the ocean...!  This voyage is cursed!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Cursed?

Speaker: alonso
Dialogue: We set sail for greed.  God has abandoned us.  The voyage is cursed. There are signs...

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: This boy has the voice of an angel. What comes out of his mouth is blessed, Alonso.  What comes out of your is evil.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Listen to me!  Every man is afraid who does something for the first time.  But those who overcome their fears, will find their rewards.  I do not know if it is God's will that we cross this ocean -- but I am certain it is the devil who puts fears into our hearts...

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: This jacket to the first man who sights land!  I want a man up that mast day and night.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: You start first.

Speaker: mendez
Dialogue: Alonso!  Jaime!  Don't let this wind escape us.

Speaker: pinzon
Dialogue: You lucky bastard...

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Pinzon, the more I sail, the luckier I get.

Speaker: mendez
Dialogue: Shall I take my turn?

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Mendez!  Mendez!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Land...

Speaker: ship's boy
Dialogue: TIERRA...!  TIERRA!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: By the... by the Grace of... God...

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: In the name of their Gracious Majesties of Castille and Aragon, and by all the powers vested in me, I claim this island and name it San Salvador.

Speaker: mendez
Dialogue: Arquebuses!

Speaker: pinzon
Dialogue: Colon!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: We have come here in peace, and we will behave with honor.  They are not savages and neither will you be. Treat these people as you would your own wives and your own children. Neither are you free to take what you will; for a seashell you give a bandana.  You will respect their beliefs.  Pillage will be punished by the whip.  Rape by the sword.

Speaker: pinzon
Dialogue: Gold...!  Gold!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Give it to him!

Speaker: pinzon
Dialogue: By God!  That's the worst trade of my life!

Speaker: old indian
Dialogue: Cuba!  Cuba!

Speaker: utapan
Dialogue: Say not here!  Cuba!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: What is it?  A tribe?  An island?

Speaker: utapan
Dialogue: Island.  Far.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Help him!

Speaker: sailor
Dialogue: Do something!  Help him!

Speaker: utapan
Dialogue: He dead.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Utapan!  Wait!

Speaker: pinzon
Dialogue: Well... You'll have to continue without me...

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: No.  It's enough.  What would you say to a drop of Jerez, Pinzon?

Speaker: pinzon
Dialogue: And a nice slice of Santa Fe lamb! I'd sell my soul for it.  Help me up.  I've got to piss, gold.

Speaker: utapan
Dialogue: He cures.

Speaker: utapan
Dialogue: You come!  You speak first!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Tell the Chief we thank him.

Speaker: utapan
Dialogue: Chief knows.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Tell him his country is very beautiful.  Tell him we are leaving men here -- to build a fort.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Tell him we will return very soon. Many of us.

Speaker: utapan
Dialogue: Chief says -- how many?

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Thousands.

Speaker: utapan
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: To bring the word of God.

Speaker: utapan
Dialogue: Chief says -- he has a God.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: ... and also to bring medicine.

Speaker: utapan
Dialogue: Chief says...

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Tell him we admire his people.

Speaker: utapan
Dialogue: Chief says he knows you like his...  Women...

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: That's a beginning...

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Get below!  All of you!  Go!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Stay with me!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: We may have to cut it!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: I'll stay here -- to decide if we cut it.  Help me!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Now go!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: I said -- below deck, Mendez!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: One... two... three... four...

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Damn you!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: One... two... three... four... five...

Speaker: arojaz
Dialogue: It won't be easy to get rid of your prophet now, Don Sanchez.

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: On the contrary, Your Eminence.  It seems to me the man is preparing his own cross.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: You must not inhale, but simply allow the palate to enjoy the flavor of the Tobacco...

Speaker: moxica
Dialogue: And you say this is an Indian vice? By God!  I don't see any kind of pleasure that would make this a sin.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: The Indians have no such word, Don Moxica.

Speaker: isabel
Dialogue: Do they have such thoughts?

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: They come and go as naked as the day God created them...

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: They don't see sin in their nakedness.  They live according to nature, in a never ending summer. The islands are covered with trees, filled with blossoms and fruits. And...

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: Forgive me, Don Colon.  But what about gold?

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: These are gifts for Your Majesty.

Speaker: isabel
Dialogue: We are more than gratified.

Speaker: master
Dialogue: Si!  Si!  Muy bien!  Excellente!

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: You defend yourself admirably...

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: ... for a commoner?

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: To your second expedition.

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: Don Colon -- Don Alonso de Bobadilla.  A man who knows our laws.

Speaker: bobadilla
Dialogue: I understand that you will soon be appointing Governors for the islands?  Is it not so?

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Forgive me, Don Bobadilla -- those positions have already been taken.

Speaker: bobadilla
Dialogue: May I ask by whom?

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Bartolome and Giacomo Colon.

Speaker: bobadilla
Dialogue: I trust they are men of quality.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: But we do have a lack of notaries. You should contact my administration.

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: Don Bobadilla is already a judge, my Dear Don Cristobal.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Good!  We are also in need of judges.  Except there are no thieves!

Speaker: bobadilla
Dialogue: I see I was mistaken.  Don Colon has no need for my services...

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: You seem to have a special talent for making friends.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: What...?  Do I have so many already?

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: A little hypocrisy goes a long way.

Speaker: bartolome
Dialogue: You might have given us a choice!

Speaker: giacomo
Dialogue: Bartolome is stronger, more capable than I will ever be...

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: I need both of you.  What are you afraid of?  We are living what we always dreamt of.

Speaker: giacomo
Dialogue: You know I never shared those dreams with you.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Are you saying you refuse to help?

Speaker: bartolome
Dialogue: You bastard... you always had your own way...

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Let me show you something.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Of course... Of course... We'll see to it... Yes... Thank you... Soon... Soon...

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: We're brothers!  We must be a House. A bloodline!  In this country one can't exist alone!  I need you...! Both of you!

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: Where is the Admiral?  Has anyone seen the Admiral?

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: He is here!  What is it?

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Admiral!  The horses have arrived.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: I know.  I saw them!  Who did we hire today?

Speaker: assistant
Dialogue: Thirty blacksmiths, twenty eight halberdiers, twenty carpenters, a hundred farmers, twenty miners... and Doctor Chanca, the royal surgeon.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: The royal surgeon?  Then we can count on royal health!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: He's growing up!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Beatrix, I want to ask you something.

Speaker: beatrix
Dialogue: You don't usually ask.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: I can arrange for the Queen to take Fernando and Diego into her service.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: It is a great honor.  We could not hope for anything better.

Speaker: beatrix
Dialogue: For once I wish you weren't right.

Speaker: moxica
Dialogue: Is this your new world, Don Colon?

Speaker: guevara
Dialogue: These animals should be shown what savagery can be!

Speaker: nobleman
Dialogue: Three heads for every life taken. No mercy before God!

Speaker: guevara
Dialogue: No mercy!  Let's find them.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: No Guevara.  There will be no revenge.

Speaker: moxica
Dialogue: We lost cousins, friends.  We will wash this in blood.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: If you want to keep your head on your shoulders, you'll do as I say.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Moxica, I lost friends too... Thirty nine brave men who trusted me.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: You want a war?  Fine.  We are a thousand.  They outnumber us by ten! Who will you kill?  Which tribe?

Speaker: moxica
Dialogue: We don't need to know.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: We came here to stay!  To build! Not to start a crusade.  In this forest, there is enough danger to sweep us away in days!  So we will be brave and swallow our grief.  And in the name of those who died, we will accomplish what we came for.

Speaker: utapan
Dialogue: They here.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Ask the Chief what happened to my men?

Speaker: utapan
Dialogue: Another tribe made war on them... came by sea... took them away...

Speaker: brother buyl
Dialogue: God have mercy on their souls...

Speaker: moxica
Dialogue: The monkey is lying.

Speaker: moxica
Dialogue: We should kill them, Don Colon.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: No...!  you'll do it my way.  Tell the Chief we will not harm his people, even though we have the power to do it.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: We will work with his people.  We want peace.  Ask the Chief if he understands?

Speaker: utapan
Dialogue: He understands.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Ask him if he will help.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Don Moxica -- we need your horse.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: We can't raise the wheel without it.

Speaker: moxica
Dialogue: My horse doesn't work.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Don Moxica -- we all have to work.

Speaker: moxica
Dialogue: You did not hear me, Don Colon.  Not my horse.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Forgive me, Don Moxica.  But it was your horse I was talking about.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Thank you, Don Moxica.

Speaker: moxica
Dialogue: To the Governor of the Mosquitoes!

Speaker: moxica
Dialogue: Do you want her?

Speaker: guevara
Dialogue: To the new world, my friend!  To the new world!

Speaker: giacomo
Dialogue: Nima's a good cook!

Speaker: bartolome
Dialogue: She's more than that!

Speaker: giacomo
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Eat!  I'll tell you later.

Speaker: giacomo
Dialogue: I'd like to know what I'm eating.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Iguana.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: What wrong with it?  The Indians eat it!

Speaker: giacomo
Dialogue: I'm not an Indian.

Speaker: bartolome
Dialogue: He wishes he were back in the seminary.  Priests always eat well.  And they have very good cellars.

Speaker: giacomo
Dialogue: Nothing grows here!  Everything rots in the ground.  The wheat and vines wither before we can harvest them.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: We've got to learn to live like the Indians.  Eat your Iguana!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: How much gold have we found?

Speaker: bartolome
Dialogue: Not enough to justify a single shipment.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Perhaps it doesn't exist anywhere but in my imagination.

Speaker: bartolome
Dialogue: Then let's hope not...  What will happen if we can't find enough gold?

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Then I'm Governor of the Mosquitoes.

Speaker: brother buyl
Dialogue: What kind of disease is this?

Speaker: doctor chanca
Dialogue: I don't know.  It seems almost as if we have exchanged diseases with the Indians.  They die of our most common cold, and we of their plague.

Speaker: brother buyl
Dialogue: God forgive us!

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: It seems to be caused by intimacy with the native women, Your Majesty.

Speaker: isabel
Dialogue: Will he survive?

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: No, Your Majesty.  They go mad -- then they die.  There is nothing we can do.

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: Every ship returns with a cargo of sick and dying.  But with no gold! The new world proves expensive, Your Majesty.

Speaker: isabel
Dialogue: We weren't expecting immediate profits, were we?  We must have faith.  We must give time for time.

Speaker: translator
Dialogue: He says he has not found any!

Speaker: moxica
Dialogue: He's lying!

Speaker: moxica
Dialogue: Bring him here!

Speaker: moxica
Dialogue: Tell him to put his hands on the table.  Like this!

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Don Giacomo, you'd better come at once!

Speaker: moxica
Dialogue: Tell them I want them to watch this!

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Don't Moxica!  You can't...

Speaker: moxica
Dialogue: I can't?  I can't?

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: In one act of brutality, you have created chaos.  Tribes who were fighting each other are now joining forces against us!  All that because of your criminal savagery!

Speaker: moxica
Dialogue: Savagery is what monkeys understand.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: You'll be held in detention, deprived of your privileges and possessions.  Until you are returned to Spain where you will be judged. Have you anything to say?

Speaker: moxica
Dialogue: You will regret this.

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: You animals!  Can't you wait!

Speaker: bartolome
Dialogue: Moxica is right.  Our ways don't work!

Speaker: bartolome
Dialogue: Can you find them?

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: You have to find them, Utapan.  Look what they did!

Speaker: utapan
Dialogue: You did the same to your God!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: We have to stop this war.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Do you know them?

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Stop!  Stop this!

Speaker: giacomo
Dialogue: Moxica...

Speaker: moxica
Dialogue: You know what they will say in Spain about my death -- don't you?

Speaker: moxica
Dialogue: You are nothing!  You bastards will never inherit your titles.  We are everything.  We are immortal!

Speaker: brother buyl
Dialogue: I wish to go back with them, Don Colon.  I have no desire to remain in this godless place.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: You may do as you please, Brother Buyl -- though your departure will not help me to make it more Godly.

Speaker: brother buyl
Dialogue: You treat Christians equally with heathen savages.  You execute members of the nobility.  And what do you offer in return?

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: A new world, Brother Buyl.

Speaker: brother buyl
Dialogue: Nobody wants one...!  Only you!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Perhaps hope only exists in the journey.  When it begins, everything is still possible -- every expectation; every dream...

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: This is not how I imagined it to be.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Utapan!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Utapan, won't you speak to me?  You used to know how to speak to me.

Speaker: utapan
Dialogue: You never learned how to speak my language.

Speaker: indians
Dialogue: Urracan... Urracan... Urracan... Urracan...

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Let it go!  Let it go!

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: ... But there is worse.  He ordered the execution of five members of the nobility...

Speaker: isabel
Dialogue: Is this true, Brother Buyl?

Speaker: brother buyl
Dialogue: Yes, Your Majesty.  It is all true. I saw it with my own eyes.

Speaker: isabel
Dialogue: Then, what do you suggest, Don Sanchez?

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: He must be replaced.

Speaker: isabel
Dialogue: And who would you think of, for such a task?

Speaker: bobadilla
Dialogue: Don Alonso de Bobadilla.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Yes... I remember...

Speaker: bobadilla
Dialogue: My letters of appointment.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Appointment to what?

Speaker: bobadilla
Dialogue: Viceroy of the West Indies.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Congratulations.  Then I am free to search for the mainland.

Speaker: bobadilla
Dialogue: Didn't you learn?  The mainland was discovered.  Weeks ago.  By another Italian.  I forgot his name.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: How far from here?

Speaker: bobadilla
Dialogue: I am not a seaman.  But I heard it is no more than a week at sea.  I hope you are not too disappointed.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: How could I be?  The mainland has been found.  Exactly as I said it would.

Speaker: bobadilla
Dialogue: I am afraid this is not the worst news.

Speaker: fernando
Dialogue: Father?

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Fernando...!  My God...!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: A man!  Diego, how did this happen?

Speaker: diego
Dialogue: Santangel is going to see the Queen. We are going to get you out of here.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Good!  I have to go back!

Speaker: diego
Dialogue: Go back?

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: I have to explore the mainland.

Speaker: fernando
Dialogue: This time with me!

Speaker: diego
Dialogue: In your present state it is madness, Father!

Speaker: fernando
Dialogue: Nobody is forcing you to come with us.

Speaker: diego
Dialogue: I can't go anyway.

Speaker: fernando
Dialogue: She's very beautiful!  The Queen has very good taste.  Diego is getting married.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: I am happy for you, Diego.

Speaker: santangel
Dialogue: Granted his faults.  Yes, a hundred times!  But the man is still remarkable.

Speaker: santangel
Dialogue: All he asks is a chance to explore this... mainland.

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: It does not belong to him.

Speaker: santangel
Dialogue: I beg Your Majesty to receive him. To hear him... He will make no more demands.  He has changed.  He is penitent.

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: Penitent...?  He is suing us for breach of contract!

Speaker: isabel
Dialogue: Is he?

Speaker: isabel
Dialogue: Really?

Speaker: isabel
Dialogue: Rise... Please...

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Now I do look older than you.

Speaker: isabel
Dialogue: We have decided to allow you to undertake another voyage to the new world...

Speaker: isabel
Dialogue: But without your brothers.  Nor are you to return to Santo Domingo or any of the other colonies.  You may explore the continent.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: isabel
Dialogue: There is one thing I'd like to understand... Why do you want to go back, after all this?

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Your Majesty -- some men are content to read about things.  I must see them with my own eyes.  I cannot be other than I am.

Speaker: isabel
Dialogue: I know, I should not tolerate his impertinence.

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: Then why?

Speaker: isabel
Dialogue: Because he is not afraid of me.

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: All I have to do is call the guards.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Call them.

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: I am not afraid of you.  You are nothing but a dreamer.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Look out of that window.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: What do you see?

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: Roofs... towers, palaces... spires...

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: All of them created by people like me.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: No matter how long you live, Sanchez, there's something that will never change between us.  I did it! You didn't!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: God... you're so beautiful!  I can't believe no other man has ever taken you away from me...

Speaker: beatrix
Dialogue: They tried... but I didn't let them.

Speaker: beatrix
Dialogue: They took everything...

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Not everything... Do you think I care?  I'm a free man again.  Riches don't make a man rich, they only make him busier...

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: God, how much I've missed you!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: I owe you everything, Santangel... but as you see, I can't repay you.

Speaker: santangel
Dialogue: On the contrary.  It is I who owe you everything.  Through you, I have been an adventurer, an explorer! It's true I shall never see the new world... but it's here...

Speaker: santangel
Dialogue: What you are, Colon, is a sailor, a discoverer, a man of imagination... not a politician.  You weren't meant to govern -- You cannot be all things to all men.

Speaker: santangel
Dialogue: I wish you could have compromised. It would have made your life easier...

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: But as least we haven't been bored, have we?

Speaker: sailor's voice
Dialogue: West... southwest, Captain Mendez...

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: How are you feeling, Fernando?

Speaker: fernando
Dialogue: Not bad.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: You know what I always used to do?

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Swallow a piece of pork fat on a string.  It always worked.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: The mainland...

Speaker: mendez
Dialogue: What's he doing?

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: He's drawing an isthmus... He's saying we're on an isthmus.

Speaker: mendez
Dialogue: We can't be.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Tell me what he's saying.

Speaker: translator
Dialogue: He says -- water on the other side.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Ask him if he means a lake.  A big lake.

Speaker: translator
Dialogue: No.  Says those are lakes.  Water on other side big -- as wide as here. Above and below, much land.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: An ocean...?  He's says it's an ocean?

Speaker: fernando
Dialogue: I don't understand.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Here is Europe... and over here, the continent of Asia.  But there's something in between!  Another continent!  We've found... another continent!

Speaker: fernando
Dialogue: Father...

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: There must be a passage to that other ocean.

Speaker: translator
Dialogue: I help.

Speaker: fernando
Dialogue: Oh my God...

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: What is...?

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: Oh Virgen Maria... Oh Madre de Dios...

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: Jesus, Maria, y todos los Santos...

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Out!  Get out!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Take it.  Come on.  Drink.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: I... I have to see Mendez.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Your brother was right.  I should have never taken you with me.  I'll never forgive myself.  Never!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Will you ever forgive me?

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Captain Mendez!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: I came to Your Highness with honest purpose and sincere zeal.  I did not undertake these voyages for honor or wealth -- that is certain.  After years of service to the Crown, I do not have a roof to put over my head... Your Majesty allowed me to explore the continent, believed to be Asia.  I now believe that it is an new Land, of unknown proportions and wealth... Life has more imagination than we carry in our dreams...

Speaker: duena
Dialogue: "I should be judged as a Seaman who by Divine Will discovered a New World, and thereby placed it under the sovereignty of Your Majesties. I humbly beseech Your Majesties that if it pleases God to remove me hence, you will help the name of Columbus to be remembered with honor... Weep for me, whoever has charity, truth and justice."

Speaker: arojaz
Dialogue: ... West by south west for 750 leagues to Santo Domingo.  From there, west north west, leaving San Juan to the north, reaching the island of Hispanola on the northern cape of San Raphael... Then onto the mainland, at the Cape called Gracias a Dios...

Speaker: arojaz
Dialogue: Spain -- by Your Majesty's grace -- has confirmed for all humanity the existence of an unknown continent... Tierra Incognita...

Speaker: arojaz
Dialogue: ... This continent was first discovered by a sailor commissioned by your Majesty...

Speaker: arojaz
Dialogue: His name... Amerigo Vespucci...

Speaker: arojaz
Dialogue: My God...!  I thought he was dead.

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: You can see for yourself.

Speaker: arojaz
Dialogue: What a tragedy... what a waste of a life...

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: A waste...?  Let me tell you something, Arojaz.  If your name, or mine, is ever remembered -- it will only be because of his.

Speaker: marchena
Dialogue: I suppose we're both old men now.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: You'll always be older than me, Father.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Have you ever forgiven me?

Speaker: marchena
Dialogue: Yes.  I forgave you a long time ago. You see, I was proud of you.  You were like a willful child.  You wouldn't accept what others told you.  You had to find things out for yourself, hurting yourself -- and others -- in the process.

Speaker: marchena
Dialogue: Do you remember when you said that people talk about the world, but never leave their gardens.

Speaker: marchena
Dialogue: More than ever I wonder what it is we do achieve by leaving our gardens... The world changes -- and yet it seems the same.  We find new worlds, but fill them with the same people...

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: I have to disagree.

Speaker: marchena
Dialogue: I knew you would.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: New worlds create new people.

Speaker: marchena
Dialogue: Oh?  So you are a new man?

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: I don't know... I have the impression that I didn't change that much.  I still can't accept the world as it is!

Speaker: marchena
Dialogue: God bless you, and those like you!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Can't you stay with us a little?

Speaker: beatrix
Dialogue: I am busy inside.

Speaker: beatrix
Dialogue: What is it, now?  Tell me...

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: I can't keep my eyes off you.  I would like to catch up with all the moments I didn't spend with you.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: What are you listening to?

Speaker: fernando
Dialogue: I am not listening, Father.  But I can't help hearing.

Speaker: fernando
Dialogue: It's Diego... He is at the Court, with Santangel... He says they hope to get your privileges restored... And maybe the house.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: But how is he?  And Dona Maria?

Speaker: fernando
Dialogue: Fine, it seems.  Diego is thinking of starting a pearl trade, in Santo Domingo... He says he received many letters for you.  Some of your men, mostly.

Speaker: fernando
Dialogue: This one is from Mendez!

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: What does he say?

Speaker: fernando
Dialogue: He asks when he can come to visit you.  He left his address.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: He never had one... except aboard my ships!

Speaker: fernando
Dialogue: I want you to tell me everything you remember, Father.  From the beginning.  Everything.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: Really?  God... I wouldn't know where to start... and yet...

Speaker: fernando
Dialogue: Tell me the first thing that comes to your mind.

Speaker: columbus
Dialogue: I remember...
